div1.p: In the Circuit Court of the United States for the W. Dist. of Washington, Northern Division
In re application of Columbia George for writ of Habeas Corpus
Answer and return to order to show cause
Filed Mar 26, 1906. A Reeves Ayres, Clerk. By A. N. Moore, Deputy
In the United States Circuit Court for the Western District of Washington, Northern Division
In the Matter of the Application of Columbia George, for a Writ of Habeas Corpus. No. 1390.
Answer and Return to the Order to Show Cause Issued Herein.

In obedience to the order to show cause heretofore issued in this matter, come now the respondents, C.B. Hopkins, United States Marshal for the Western District of Washington, and the United States of America, by Jesse A. Frye, United States Attorney for the Western DIstrict of Washington, and in answer to the petition adn order to show cause filed and issued herein, stating that while said peition on file herein is not paged, paragraphed nor the lines numbered, it being therefore difficult to put the return thereto in systematic form, but waiving said irregularity, certify, return and answer as follows:

The respondents deny, generally and specifically, each and every allegation, and each and every part thereof, contained on teh first page of said petition, except that the petitioner, Columbia George, together with one Toy Toy, was on the 21st day of October 1901 indicted by a Grand Jury of the United States of America sitting in and for the District of Oregon, and that thereafter said petitioner was tried in said court upon said indictment, and convicted of murder without capital punishment and sentenced to be imprisoned at hard labor for life in the

Oregon State Penitentiary at Salem, Oregon, and thereafter by order of the Attorney General of the United States said petitioner was transferred to the custody of C.B. Hopkins, United States Marshal for the Western District of Washington, and that said petitioner is now in the cusotdy of said United States Marshal for the Western District of Washington in the United States Penitentiary on McNeills Island, Washington.

The respondents deny generally and specifically each and every allegation and each and every part thereof contained on page two of said petition, except that Columbia George is now and was at the time of the indictment set forth in paragraph One of this return, a full blood Indian, and that the person mentioned in said indictment as having been murdered by said Columbia George and Toy Toy, was a full blood Indian, and that said crime was committed on the Umatila Indian Reservation in the State of Oregon, and that the said Columbia George and Toy Toy were at the time said murder was committed, tribal Indians belonging to the Cayuse Band of Indians, and resided upon said Umatilla Reservation.

And respondents for a further return to said petition and order to show cause, state that on the 21st day of October 1901, at Portland, Oregon, in the Circuit Court of the United States for the District of Oregon, an indictment was returned against the applicant and petitioner, Columbia George, jointly with Toy Toy, which said indictment was and is in the words and figures following, to-wit:

body.p: In the Circuit Court of the United States District of Oregon
{United States of America, vs. Columbia George and Toy Toy} No. 2699.

The Grand Jurors of the United States of America, choosen, selected and sworn within and for the District of Oregon, in the name and by the authority of the United States of America, upon their oaths do find and present:

That Columbia George, an Indian, and Toy Toy, an Indian, did on the 24th day of August 1900, upon the Umatilla Indian Reaservation, within the State and District of Oregon, purposely and of thier deliberate and premeditated malice and forethought kill and murder one, Annie Edna, an Indian woman, by then and there administering to her the said Annie Edna, a lethal dose of poison, namely, strychnine, from which said Columbia George and Toy Toy, Indians aforesaid, the said Annie Edna then and there died, contrary to the form of the statute in such case made and provided, and against the statute in such case made and provided, and against the peace and dignity of the United States of America.
Dated at Portland, Oregon, this 21st day of October 1901.
Chas. E. Ladd, Foreman of United States Grand Jury.
John H. Hall, United States District Attorney.

That thereafter a trial was had of said Columbia George and Toy Toy in the above entitled court upon said indictment, and the said Columbia George and Toy Toy were convicted of murder without capital punishment, and sentenced to imprisonment at hard labor for life in the Oregon State Penitentiary at Salem, Oregon, upon a commitment issued by the Judge of the United States Circuit Court for the District of Oregon, which said commitment was issued under a judgment in said cause rendered by the said Circuit Court of the United States for the District of Oregon, on the 3rd day of December 1901; that thereafter by an order of the Attorney General of United States, the said petitioner, Columbia George, was transferred to the custody of C.B. Hopkins, United States Marshal for the Western District of Washington,

and that said Columbia George is now in the custody of the said United States Marshal in the United States Penitentiary on McNeills Island, Washingotn, and that said petitioner is being held in said penitentiary pursant to the commitment issued by the United States Circuit Court for the District of Oregon, and pursuant to an order of the Attorney General of the United States, and that the custody of the said Columbia George by the said United States Marshal for the Western DIstrict of Washington is legal, and that the United States Circuit Court for the District of Oregon had jurisdiction in the premises, and the Attorney General of the United States had power and authority to transfer said petitioner from the Orgeon State Penitentiary at Salem, Oregon, to the custody of the United States Marshal for the western District of Washington, that the term of sentence of the saod Columbia George has not expired according to law and according to the terms of the commitment issued in the premises; that C.B. Hopkins, is now, and for a long time prior thereto has been, the duly appointed, qualified and acting United States Marshal for the Western District of Washington, and that the petitioner, Columbia George, is in his custody as such United States Marshal, and that said petitioner is now being legally detained in the United States Penitentiary on McNeills Island, State of Washingotn; that at the time of the return of said indictment as herinabove set forth the said Columbia George and the said Toy Toy were full blodd Indians, and that the person murdered by them was a full blood Indian, and that the crime commited by them was commited upon the Umatilla Indian Reservation in the State of Oregon,

and that the said Columbia Goerge was at the time of the return of said indictment and at the time of his trial and commitmet, and is now, a tribal Indian belonging to the Cayuse Band on Indians, and that at the time of the commision of said crime and during said trial, and until sentenced, he was residing upon said Umatilla Inidan Reservation in the State of Oregon:

WHEREFORE, your respondents having shown to this Honorable Court that said petitioner is held by due and lawful process, prays that said rule and order to show cause herein, be quashed , and that said prisoner be held to await the expiration of his sentence as provided by law.
Jesse A. Faye United States Attorney for the Western District of Washington
